'''Karen Hunter''' is an American [[Journalism|journalist]] and [[publisher]], and the coauthor of several books.
==Education== Hunter has a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in English Literature from [[Drew University]].
==Career== Between 1996 and 1998, Hunter taught journalism at [[New York University]].
Hunter spent four years as a part of the [[New York Daily News]]' seven-member editorial board. In 1999, she was a concurrent member of respective news teams that won the [[Pulitzer Prize]] and the Polk Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aalbc.com/authors/karen_hunter.htm|title=Karen Hunter|work=AALBC.Com(The African American Literature Book Club)|accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> Prior to that she was the paperâs first African-American female news columnist. She joined the newspaper as a sports writer in 1988, then wrote features and business stories.
In January 2002, Hunter was appointed by the [[Hunter College]] administration as an Assistant Visiting Professor in the Department of Film and Media Studies and presently is a Distinguished Lecturer at Hunter College. She also was a morning radio talk show host for three years in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blackspeakers.com/profiles/karen_hunter.shtml|title=Karen Hunter|work=Black Speakers.Com|accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref>
In 2006 she left her position as a morning talk show host on New York station (1600 AM) [[WWRL]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nycpba.org/pdf/malzberg.pdf|title=Steve Malzberg Joins WWRL 1600 AM|date=October 29, 2004|accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> Her departure followed the dissolution of an early morning team composed of her and [[WABC (AM)|WABC]] personality [[Steve Malzberg]].
In 2007, she launched Karen Hunter Publishing, an imprint of Pocket Books/[[Simon & Schuster]]. She has published "Why Black Men Love White Women," "Faith Under Fire," "Love On A Two-Way Street," "Recipes for a Good Life," with Patti Labelle and epic griotsong "The Children of Children Keep Coming," with Wall Street pioneer [[Russell L. Goings]]. As a writer, Hunter has co-authored five New York Times best-sellers, among which are books with [[Queen Latifah]], [[Al Sharpton]], [[Mason Betha]], [[Karrine Steffans]], [[LL Cool J]], [[Wendy Williams (radio host)|Wendy Williams]], [[J. L. King]], [[Donda West]], [[Sandy Denton]], [[Cedric the Entertainer]], and [[Jonathan Plummer]].<ref>[http://www.harpercollins.com/global_scripts/product_catalog/author_xml.asp?authorid=27417 Karen Hunter] author bio</ref>
On January 31, 2007 Hunter appeared on CNN's ''[[Paula Zahn]] Now'' in a piece on [[Atheism|atheists]] in America. During the open forum portion she made several controversial comments suggesting that "If they [atheists] had Hallmark cards, maybe they wouldn't feel so left out. We have Christmas cards. We have [[Kwanzaa]] cards now. Maybe they need to get some atheist cards and get that whole ball rolling so more people can get involved with what they're doing. I think they need to shut up and let people do what they do."<ref>[http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0701/31/pzn.01.html CNN transcript: Paula Zahn Now: Senator Joe Biden Under Fire Over Controversial Remarks; Has NFL Moved Beyond Racist Past?] January 31, 2007</ref>
On April 11, 2011, on her Facebook page Hunter called for a boycott of the television show [[Celebrity Apprentice]] in reactions to comments Trump made about Barack Obama.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blackamericaweb.com/?q=articles/news/the_state_of_black_america_news/27520/2|title=Should Blacks Respond to Trump Birther Stance?|author=Sean Yoes|work=BlackAmericaWeb.com|date=April 13, 2011|accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref> She said in a later interview: "So many of us were angered and outraged by Trumpâs comments and I wanted to let us know that we have power. We can do something besides grumble and complain." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediablvd.com/magazine/the_news/celebrity/publishing_magnate,_karen_hunter,_organizes_boycott_of_%93celebrity_apprentice%94_201105092498.html|title=Publishing Magnate, Karen Hunter, Organizes Boycott of âCelebrity Apprenticeâ|author=Frederic Germay|work=MediaBlvd Magazine|date=May 9, 2011|accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref>
==Personal== Hunter resides in [[Orange, New Jersey]].
